summary: 5853 calves, housed in 15 production cohorts, were followed during one production cycle. main causes of mortality were pneumonia, ruminal disorders, idiopathic peritonitis and enteritis. mortality and morbidity is hardly documented in veal calves. previous studies addressed mortality in veal calves housed in individual stalls. this housing system has been completely abandoned in Europe. the study population consisted of all veal herds in Flanders certified by the Belgian Controlled Veal (BCV) label. of the 295 herds in Belgium, 285 herds (97%) are situated in Flanders and 271 herds (95%) complied with the BCV label. unwanted early slaughter was defined as calves being individually slaughtered before the rest of the group, mostly for reasons of trauma or sudden respiratory symptoms. a gross postmortem examination of the animals which died during production was performed either on farm or at the animal health service-Flanders. inal disorders included frothy bloat and acute ruminal acidosis/rumenitis. cases were classified as enteritis when a macroscopic enteritis and obvious smearing of the hind legs were present at necropsy. calves were classified as idiopathic peritonitis if at least a peritonitis was present. a commercial antigen ELISA for Cryptosporidium parvum, bovine coronavirus, bovine rotavirus and Escherichia coli (F5) was performed on intestinal content (Digestive ELISA kit, Bio-X, Jemelle, Belgium) the presence of bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) was examined by PCR on spleen tissue. a calf was considered a case of a given disease, when treated individually for that indication on at least one day by the producer or veterinarian. a relapse case was defined as a calf receiving a new treatment for the same indication more than 5 and less than 15 days after the last treatment for that indication. Mortality/morbidity rates were calculated as the number of mortalities/diseased calves (initial and relapse) over the number of calf-days-at-risk. for morbidity a calf was considered at risk when present alive in the cohort and not individually treated in the past 14 days. the end of the observation period was the date of slaughter, if death hadn't occurred. separate multivariable models were fit with total morbidity, BRD, enteritis, otitis and arthritis as binary outcome variables. a production cohort was defined as one all in all out production cycle. the study group consisted of 15 production cohorts, in 15 herds. the sample was stratified on production system: dairy (n = 5), crossbred (n = 5) and beef (n = 5) cohorts. pneumonia cases with concurrent pleuritis or pericarditis were classified as pneumonia cases. ruminal disorders included enteritis, enterotoxaemia, mesenteric torsion, intussusception, liver disease, abomasal hemorrhage and peritonitis due to perforating abomasal ulceration. omphalitis as such, omphalo-urachitis, omphaloarteritis and umbilical abscesses were classified according to the major lesion. the group of neurological disorders included hydranencephalia, hydrocephalus and meningitis. calves with congenital heart defects were classified as such. no other significant associations between production system and diseases. significant herd effects were detected for total morbidity and all other assessed diseases. in the present study, the mortality risk (5,3%) was higher than previously reported for white veal calves in Canada (3,7%), the united states (2,5% and 4,2%) and Switzerland (3,0%) the most likely explanation is probably the longer production cycle (28 weeks) compared to previously studied systems (16-21 weeks), which increased the days at risk. a second explanatory factor might be the housing system. high mortality risks (8.2%) have been reported in farms which purchase young calves from different origin. mortality risk in veal calves was similar to live born calves in dairy replacement herds in Great Britain (5.0%), Norway (4,6%), Sweden (4.0%) and crossbred cow-calf farms in Switzerland (5.0%). hydranencephalia was associated with the 2007 bluetongue outbreak in northern Europe. salmonella spp. are historically reported as one of the major causes of mortality in veal calves in Belgium. but the bacteria could not be isolated from any of the suspicious cases. in contrast to conventional dairy calves, diarrhea and respiratory disease occurred simultaneously in the first three weeks after arrival, which is most likely a consequence of commingling. the long tail of the BRD mortality and morbidity curve is explained by a large proportion of chronic BRD cases (reoccurent and relapse) as in feedlot calves, synergy between M. bovis and BVDV is the cause of chronic, unresponsive pneumonia, often in association with arthritis and otitis (M. bovis associated disease) enterotoxaemia almost exclusively occurred in Belgian blue veal calves. the identity of the toxin and the exact pathogenesis are still unclear. idiopathic peritonitis emerged only recently in veal calves. BVDV was associated with chronic pneumonia and pleuritis at necropsy. authors declare that they have no competing interests.
